title: Fix append method of TTree
body: Fixes #336

title: Fix issue340
body:
Fixes #340 
My understanding of the fLast attribute of the TKey of TBaskets was wrong.
Added some more tests.

title: Fixed extend for flush=True
body:
Fixes extend with flush=True (even though it is still using the inefficient implementation of flush=False).
Even after the better(and correct) implementation of flush=False for extend, the code under the flush=True block should probably not change.

Although, in its current implementation this makes extend=True less efficient, the implementation is now correct.

title: vector<uint_64> is read as jagged array of dtype uint32
body:
Hi!
I have a root file with "events" each of it having 

```c++
std::vector<uint64_t> hit_trk_id
```

When I open the file with root and print the branch info

```
root [13] b->Print()
*Br    0 :hit_trk_id : vector<unsigned long>                                 *
*Entries :      100 : Total  Size=     161079 bytes  File Size  =      16628 *
*Baskets :        6 : Basket Size=      32000 bytes  Compression=   9.66     *
*............................................................................*
```

When I open it with uproot:

```
events = uproot.open("data/g4e_test_herwig_100ev_2019-09.root")['events']
events.show()
```
The result:
```
...
hit_trk_id                 TStreamerSTL               asjagged(asdtype('>u4'), 10)
...
```
So it is 32 bits and the data is kind of corrupted if read without an explicit interpretation:
```python
print(events.array('hit_trk_id').flatten())   # flatten is for simplicity
```
gives
```
array([    0,  1021,     0, ..., 11801,     0, 11802], dtype=uint32)
```
(zeroes and dtype)

The workaround is something like:

```python
skip_bytes = 0
if isinstance(events['hit_trk_id'], asjagged):
    skip_bytes = asjagged.skipbytes
events['hit_trk_id'].array(asjagged(asdtype(np.uint64), skip_bytes))   # prints tree contents
```

But I believe it is a bug. 
The root file is attached. 

P.S. are skip_bytes always 10? 


[g4e_test_herwig_100ev_2019-09.zip](https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/files/3632337/g4e_test_herwig_100ev_2019-09.zip)

title: Error reading with uproot root files, with TTree, written with uproot
body:
Hi I tried the example in the README to write TTree in root file but when I try to read it back I get the following error.

```
In [1]: import uproot

In [2]: import numpy as np

In [3]: with uproot.recreate("example.root") as f:
   ...:     f["t"] = uproot.newtree({"normal": np.float64})
   ...:     f["t"].extend({"normal": np.random.normal(0, 1, 10000)})
   ...:

In [4]: t = uproot.open("example.root")["t"]

In [5]: t
Out[5]: <TTree b't' at 0x00010e1e50f0>

In [6]: t.arrays()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AssertionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-6-6502dc56ca9a> in <module>
----> 1 t.arrays()

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py in arrays(self, branches, outputtype, namedecode, entrystart, entrystop, flatten, flatname, awkwardlib, cache, basketcache, keycache, executor, blocking)
    513
    514         # start the job of filling the arrays
--> 515         futures = [(branch.name if namedecode is None else branch.name.decode(namedecode), interpretation, branch.array(interpretation=interpretation, entrystart=entrystart, entrystop=entrystop, flatten=(flatten and not ispandas), awkwardlib=awkward, cache=cache, basketcache=basketcache, keycache=keycache, executor=executor, blocking=False)) for branch, interpretation in branches]
    516
    517         # make functions that wait for the filling job to be done and return the right outputtype

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py in <listcomp>(.0)
    513
    514         # start the job of filling the arrays
--> 515         futures = [(branch.name if namedecode is None else branch.name.decode(namedecode), interpretation, branch.array(interpretation=interpretation, entrystart=entrystart, entrystop=entrystop, flatten=(flatten and not ispandas), awkwardlib=awkward, cache=cache, basketcache=basketcache, keycache=keycache, executor=executor, blocking=False)) for branch, interpretation in branches]
    516
    517         # make functions that wait for the filling job to be done and return the right outputtype

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py in array(self, interpretation, entrystart, entrystop, flatten, awkwardlib, cache, basketcache, keycache, executor, blocking)
   1360             keycache = {}
   1361
-> 1362         basket_itemoffset = self._basket_itemoffset(interpretation, basketstart, basketstop, keycache)
   1363         basket_entryoffset = self._basket_entryoffset(basketstart, basketstop)
   1364

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py in _basket_itemoffset(self, interpretation, basketstart, basketstop, keycache)
   1315         for j, key in enumerate(self._threadsafe_iterate_keys(keycache, True, basketstart, basketstop)):
   1316             i = basketstart + j
-> 1317             numitems = interpretation.numitems(key.border, self.basket_numentries(i))
   1318             basket_itemoffset.append(basket_itemoffset[-1] + numitems)
   1319         return basket_itemoffset

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/uproot/interp/numerical.py in numitems(self, numbytes, numentries)
    150         dtype, shape = _dtypeshape(self.fromdtype)
    151         quotient, remainder = divmod(numbytes, dtype.itemsize)
--> 152         assert remainder == 0
    153         return quotient
    154

AssertionError:
```

title: Working with std::vector<std::string>
body:
Before I write that things below, thank you very much for your uproot effort!

Now working with `std::vector<std::string>` seems a bit difficult. 

As an example I have a ROOT file where each event has hits information. Something like:

```c++
vector<double> hit_x
vector<double> hit_y
vector<double> hit_z
vector<string> hit_vol_name
```
While all vector<double> work like a charm, the interpretation of `hit_vol_name` is 

```
hit_vol_name        TStreamerSTL               asgenobj(STLVector(STLString()))
hit_x                      TStreamerSTL               asjagged(asdtype('>f8'), 10)
hit_y                      TStreamerSTL               asjagged(asdtype('>f8'), 10)
hit_z                      TStreamerSTL               asjagged(asdtype('>f8'), 10)
```

And it causes problems, when converted to pandas, for example:

![Screenshot from 2019-09-17 10-00-10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4732545/65048473-2db5eb80-d932-11e9-8747-e15b010672cc.png)

And then I have to do the first round of conversions:

```python
from awkward import JaggedArray
import awkward
a = JaggedArray.fromiter(file['events']['hit_vol_name'].array())
```
But then it is byte strings, so like in #228 one has to do something like:

```python
import numpy as np
b = a.flatten().regular().astype('U')
```
In this case flattening was Ok, but... 

It seems both inefficient and inconvenient. Or are there better workarounds?

title: Issues reading some TRef arrays
body:
To start with thank you so much for implementing TRef reading, it's been amazing. 
I have almost finished refactoring to get rid of all my previous work arounds.

One thing that doesn't quite work yet is the TRefs that appear in Towers.
One Tower is created by the energy deposits of multiple particles, so each tower gets a list of references (might be a TRefArray object, not quite sure...).

In the same root file as last time (https://mega.nz/#F!afB2SSwC!3C8bp5xY_d01VvXmkh1nJQ);
event_n|tower_n|particle_n
0|0|[1413, 1417, 1470, 1570]
0|1|[1446]
0|2|[1571]
0|3|[1763]
0|4|[1568]
...
As you can see the first tower is linked to 4 particles.

A minimal broken example of this would be;
```
import uproot
file_name = "/path/to/h1bBatch2.root"
root_file = uproot.open(file_name)['Delphes']
problem_array = root_file.array('Tower.Particles')
print(problem_array)  # expected a list of TRef objects. Possibly a TRefArray?
# error! see below
```
The error message I get from this is at the bottom (but I'm not sure how informative it is).

Thanks again for all your work on this.
- Henry

title: Fixes issue #327.
body:
The regular expression that derives streamer names from TBranch-defining comments was too naive: the type name is in parentheses, but the _last_ set of parentheses. ALICE uses parentheses in its comments for other purposes.

Fixed the bug, added a test, and bumped the version number.

title: Implemented TRef as an object that can live in TTrees.
Fixes issue #243 (again) for a file made from a new version of ROOT.
How can I follow a TRef?
body:
Apologies for the naive question, I cannot seem to grasp how to follow a TRef to find the component it points to.

For example, I have a root file created with delphes (detector simulator). It has particles (MC truth objects), tracks and towers (observations from the simulated detector). The tracks and towers keep a TRef that points to the particle that created them. I want to follow this TRef and learn the index of the particle that made them. Getting the particle itself would probably be enough to figure out it's index (with some fuzzy comparisons).

The only method I can see on the TRef object is `tref.read(source, cursor, context, parent)` which has no doc-string available. 

How should I follow a TRef in uproot?

title: Fix memory issue (#319) by recovering all interesting branches before reading any.
Extremely large memory consumption when reading from an arbitrary location of a root file
body:
Hello,
when trying to read a chunk of data from an arbitrary location in a large root file, uproot takes all RAM memory (> 64GB) and eventually crashes. If the same file is converted to HDF5 (using `root_pandas.read_root` and `pandas.DataFrame.to_hdf`) and then the same chunk of data is read with `pandas.read_hdf` - it works fast and consumes less than 1 GB of RAM.
Is this related to some intrinsic limitation of the root file format, or there is a way to overcome this problem?
Here is a minimal code to reproduce the issue:
```python
import uproot
import pandas
f = uproot.open("data.root")
tree = f['outer_cells']
df = tree.arrays('*', outputtype=pandas.DataFrame, namedecode='utf-8',
                 entrystart=3422904, entrystop=3429655)
# the program crashes before arriving to this point
```

System information: uproot version 3.9.0, python version 3.6.7, OS CERN CentOS 7.
The data file can be found here: https://cernbox.cern.ch/index.php/s/QOUBLxRUXpek7tz (or `/eos/home-k/kandroso/share-tmp/data.root` requires lxplus access)

title: Explicitly forbid awkward 1.0 well in advance of such a thing existing.
body:
So that when awkward 1.0 arrives, most uproot users will have this restriction applied and won't accidentally get it.

This will be uproot 3.9.0 (because new cross-repo version constraints require new minor version bumps).

The first uproot that will use awkward 1.0 will be uproot 4.0.0.

@reikdas Heads up! (git merge master when this is done.)

title: LazyArray loading of `std::vector<>` branch fails with 'value too large' error
body:
Hi,

I've been experimenting with Uproot and thought I'd give it a try on a set of flat ROOT ntuples I need to make some plots from.  These guys contain a single `TTree` called `gst` which has a large, but not unreasonable number of branches (93).  Many of the branches are `std::vector<double>` or `std::vector<int>`.

I can read these vector-of-value branches fine when I open one file at a time with `uproot.open()`, pull the tree out, and use `array()` or `arrays()`, e.g.:
```
>>> f = uproot.open("/path/to/gst.root")
>>> gst = f["gst"]
>>> pdgf = gst.array("pdgf")
>>> pdgf[0]
array([2112, 2212,  211, 2212,  211], dtype=int32)
```

which is an array of pdg codes as expected.

title: ROOT cannot append objects to empty files created by uproot
Fixes fSeekFree
body: ROOT can now write objects in files created by uproot.

title: Loading aligned data from multiple TTrees - friending in uproot?
body: We're interested in using uproot to load several root files that have trees that we would typically "friend" together when analyzing in ROOT - and are particularly wondering if there is an analogy to this in uproot that would also let us read in chunks of data that are aligned along their eventID axis. It seems that loading data chunked by byte size or number of events would lead to data from different trees getting mismatched - I've attempted to illustrate this in the figure below, where it seems like reading three events at a time would result in e.g. event 2198 from "Det 1 Energy" being matched up with event 2130 from "Det 2 Energy". Do you have any suggestions for friending branches in this case, or friending branches in general? Lazy loading would be great, but being able to read in aligned data from across trees is our major concern.

title: Bug in __dir__ and __getattr__ in base.py?
body:
Hi,

When running the master of uproot (python 2.7) I see errors getting attrs or using dir() on tables etc
```
In [6]: data
Out[6]: <Table [<Row 0> <Row 1> <Row 2> ... <Row 21701> <Row 21702> <Row 21703>] at 0x00013cfaa390>

In [7]: data.jets
/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/awkward/array/base.pyc in __getattr__(self, where)
    175 
    176     def __getattr__(self, where):
--> 177         if where in super(AwkwardArray, self).__dir__():
    178            return super(AwkwardArray, self).__getattribute__(where)

AttributeError: 'super' object has no attribute '__dir__'

In [8]: dir(data)

/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/awkward/array/base.pyc in __dir__(self)
    188 
    189     def __dir__(self):
--> 190         return sorted(set(super(AwkwardArray, self).__dir__() + [x for x in self.columns if self._dir_pattern.match(x) and not keyword.iskeyword(x)]))
    191     _dir_pattern = re.compile(r"^[a-zA-Z_]\w*$")

AttributeError: 'super' object has no attribute '__dir__'

```

Changing `super(...).__dir__()` to a call to `dir(super(...))` in these two methods solves it locally

Cheers,

Carl

title: depend on awkward 0.12+ to fix tree.pandas.df
body: The `JaggedArray.index` changed its name to `JaggedArray.localindex` and apparently, `TTree.pandas.df` depended on the old name. Setting the minimum awkward version to 0.12.0 fixes that.

title: Name clash between pandas.py & pandas (python 2 on SWAN)
body:
I am using uproot on CERNs SWAN, which is hosting a jupyter notebook with a python 2 kernel. uproot 3.7.0 has been installed via `pip install --user uproot` on the SWAN node, which is essentially putting the python module into a temporary home dir on the network storage system EOS.

Now copy pasting a section from uproots examples in binder
```python
import uproot
for df in uproot.pandas.iterate("http://scikit-hep.org/uproot/examples/Zmumu.root", "events", "p[xyz]1", entrysteps=500):
    print(df[:3])
```
into the notebook, resulted in the following error:
```
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'DataFrame'
```
Luckily the Internet is big enough, that just throwing the error message into google lead me to a [useful stack overflow discussion](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20621607/module-object-has-no-attribute-dataframe), and renaming `~/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/uproot/pandas.py` to something else and replacing in `__init__.py`
```python
from uproot import pandas
```
with
```python
from uproot import somethingelse as pandas
```
really solved this problem.

I am not sure if this is just some kind of edge case or if I'm doing something silly without knowing it, but I thought I'd raise this, since other uproot users might run into this as well.

edit:
Ah, I just thought of something else.
In order to load the users python modules on SWAN, you have to start the instance with a script that modifies the environment like this:
```bash
#! /bin/env sh
export PYTHONPATH=$CERNBOX_HOME/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages:$PYTHONPATH
```
is this bad practice in some sense?

title: processing list of files via `uproot.iterate` with `executor` - no speedup?
body:
I have a list of files that I would like to process as fast as possible. For this I run this code

```
import uproot
import glob
fname = glob.glob('../exported/data16/*.root')
treename = 'data16'


import concurrent.futures
executor = concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=5) 

gen = uproot.iterate(
        fname,
        branches = ['n_jet'],
        treepath = treename,
        namedecode="utf-8",
        executor = executor
)

for g in gen:
    print(len(g['n_jet']))
```

but I fail to see a speedup as a function of the workers in the `ThreadPool`. Am I misunderstanding *what* is being parallelized. Does the speed-up only happen for multiple variables / arrays? Could it be extended to process multiple files in parallel?

title: Issues 285 286
body: Odds and ends discovered while writing the new-tutorial.ipynb.

title: Negative entrystart, entrystop is not counting from the end of the branch
body: But only for the single-array functions, not `tree.arrays` (or equivalently, `tree.pandas.df`). This should be easy to fix (it came up in writing new-tutorial.ipynb).

title: Select entrysteps base on Cache size
body:
I am using the uproot iterate for reading Filelist via xrootd as below.

```
self.cache = uproot.cache.ArrayCache(200 *1024**2)
self.it = uproot.iterate(lines, treename, branches=branches,
                                 cache=self.cache,  namedecode=decode,
                                 entrysteps=entrysteps, reportpath=True,
                                 reportfile=True, reportentries=True,
                                 xrootdsource=dict(chunkbytes=80*1024, limitbytes=100*1024**2))
```

There are several ways for the iterating. By default, uproot can auto select entrysteps by syncing each basket. However, this could results in large memory for samples with large event size, which eventually leads to memory exceeding the memory limit when running on LPC condor job and jobs got killed.

To prevent the crash above, I added the cache with 200Mb. But it seems not working as I hope from https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/uproot/tree.py#L606
The current iterative is base on start and stop. So I have to fine tune the entrysteps to a small value for all jobs (different MC processes). 

Hopefully in the future, uproot can adjust the entrysteps base on the cache size, for condor jobs etc with fixed memory.

title: Unimplemented TStreamerSTL map<long,int>, set<long>?
body:
I'm trying to read a ROOT file and I can't seem to access a custom class. I get an `Unimplemented streamer type: TStreamerSTL` error.

I think it's having trouble with the `map<long,int>` element, and if it gets past that I'm sure it will have trouble with the `set<long>`.

I've tried everything I can really think of to access these elements, really digging into the source code, but I don't understand the ROOT I/O format well enough to get anywhere.

title: memmap caching of uproot arrays
body:
I've seen that ROOT file decompression can dominate the runtime of uproot/awkward workflows. Caching the arrays in python memmap files can lift uproot/awkward runtimes from ~50 kHz to ~1 MHz [attached image]. As I discovered that uproot already supports caching for xrootd, I was wondering if and how memmap caching of arrays would fit into the core uproot library or an extension (being mindful of feature creep).

What I'm doing now is something like: `tree.arrays(["Jet_pt", "Jet_eta"], cache=True)` which creates an uncompressed memmapped cache in a predetermined location, but I'm sure you would have better ideas how to structure the possible API.

On the attached picture, the gap between the black and dashed red histograms illustrates the time spent on ROOT file decompression.
![Screenshot 2019-05-10 at 13 03 55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69717/57553681-1af82e00-7324-11e9-8c80-1e5bd9f71ba7.png)

I appreciate your thoughts!

title: Make XRootDSource fork-safe
body:
By setting the appropriate environment variable.

The bug this fixes is a hang in child processes triggered by use of uproot with XRootD files in multiprocessing or concurrent.futures process pools after doing so in the parent process.  An example that triggers the bug is below:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import concurrent.futures
import uproot

file = "root://eospublic.cern.ch//eos/root-eos/cms_opendata_2012_nanoaod/Run2012B_DoubleMuParked.root"

def read(fn):
    print("starting work")
    with uproot.open(fn) as f:
        print("opened file")
        sumw = f['Events'].numentries
    return sumw

print(read(file))

with concurrent.futures.ProcessPoolExecutor(max_workers=1) as executor:
    future = executor.submit(read, file)
    print(future.result())
```

title: Use mamba instead of conda for most builds
body:
Mamba is a prototype replacement for the conda environment solver, it can solve any environment in ~2 seconds instead of the minutes it takes conda. You can read more about it [here](https://medium.com/@wolfv/making-conda-fast-again-4da4debfb3b7).

Mamba an alpha and still has a couple of issues that cause it do behave differently to conda. I think it should be stable enough here with the extra constraints I've added and it makes the testing a lot faster but I understand if don't want to merge this.

title: Fix iteration over DataFrames and provide more interfaces
body:
This PR fixes #263 and provides new methods and functions:

   * `tree.pandas.iterate` is like `tree.pandas.df` in that it sets some Pandas-friendly defaults, but on `tree.iterate`, rather than `tree.arrays`.
   * `uproot.pandas.iterate` sets those Pandas-friendly defaults on `uproot.iterate`.

Various bugs were fixed. For instance, `tree.iterate` really wasn't Pandas-ready: it had fallen considerably behind `tree.arrays`, but fortunately most of the Pandas-specific stuff is in a function call now, so no code duplication was needed to get `tree.iterate` up to speed and now it will inherit any future updates.

Also, `globalentrystart` setting in `uproot.iterate` was broken for Pandas DataFrames, both for `MultiIndex` and for `RangeIndex`. The original code seemed to be expecting `Int64Index` for some reason.

All in all, the combination of iterate + Pandas was just out of date with respect to the changes that have been more fully tested on arrays + Pandas.

title: MultiIndex pandas dataframe from uproot.iterate
body:
Hi! First of all thank you very much for this awesome package!

I have a question regarding MultiIndex pandas dataframes and uproot.iterate. When I open a ROOT file via uproot.open, I am able to select branches which contain JaggedArrays with the same dimensionality, and make them into a pandas dataframe with MultiIndex. For example:

```
mytree = uproot.open(myfile)["mytree"]
mytree.pandas.df(['muonPt', 'muonEta', 'muonPhi'])
```

Depending on the event, I can have (say) 0, 1, or 2 muons, so I can have accordingly 0, 1, or 2 subentries, and the resulting pandas dataframe reflects that.

But I would like to process several files with the same structure using uproot.iterate. I haven't found a way to make the pandas dataframe with MultiIndex by selecting the right branches from the iterate, e.g.:

```
for arrays in uproot.iterate(listoffiles, "mytree", ['muonPt', 'muonEta', 'muonPhi'], outputtype=pd.DataFrame, executor=executor):
         listofdataframes.append(arrays)
pd.concat(listofdataframes)
```

Without "flatten=True" in the iterate command above, the dataframes come out containing JaggedArrays, and I'm not sure how to turn those into a MultiIndex structure. If I do include "flatten=True", however, I get an error about incompatible dimensionalities:

> ValueError: Shape of passed values is (1, 1382), indices imply (1, 1466)


(I think this is because of the variable number of muons per entry). Is there a way to get the same behavior from uproot.iterate on many files, as I would from tree.pandas.df() on a single file?

Thank you!
Andre

title: Enable ZLIB and LZMA compression while writing
body:
Fixes #181 
I have only tested creating compressed ROOT files containing TObjStrings so far. Once that works perfectly I will start looking at files containing TH1s. 
ZLIB and LZMA compressed files can be read by uproot but not by ROOT. 
The current interface only allows the user to set the compression algorithm and compression level while creating the file and does not let the user change it after.

title: Let flat pandas dataframes have the same index format as jagged dfs
body:
Adds an argument to futures2df function to respect entrystart in output dataframe.  Although it's an optional argument for futures2df, I'm not actually passing it through from `pandas.df` or `arrays` at this point, so it's essentially always enabled (since that's the default parameter).   I can set this up, but I was unsure if we want to add this argument to `arrays` since it's only meaningful if the outputtype is a pandas dataframe.

Addresses issue #256.

(Apologies, I accidentally pushed this as a new branch to the uproot repo, rather than my own fork -- happy to close, delete branch, and re-open from my fork.)

title: Index of tree.pandas.df doesnt use entrystart for flat arrays
body:
If `tree.pandas.df` is used with `entrystart > 0` and a jagged-array is one of the requested branches, then the resulting index (with the default `flatten=True` option) is a multindex with entry and subentry columns and entry values ranging  from `entrystart` to `entrystop`.  This is different to if only flat branches are requested, however, the index is just the row number going from `0` to `entrystop - entrystart`:

```python
In [0]: 
import uproot
tree = uproot.open("CMS_HEP_tutorial_ww.root")["events"]
```
```python
In [1]: tree.pandas.df(["NMuon", "NElectron"], entrystart=100, entrystop=200).head()
Out[1]: 
   NMuon  NElectron
0      1          0
1      1          0
2      1          0
3      1          0
4      1          0
```
```python
In [2]: tree.pandas.df(["NMuon", "Muon_Px"], entrystart=100, entrystop=200).head()
Out[2]: 
                NMuon    Muon_Px
entry subentry                  
100   0           1.0 -45.877728
101   0           1.0 -47.455692
102   0           1.0  54.362259
103   0           1.0 -30.484287
104   0           1.0   6.948876
```

I was wondering if we could be an optional argument that makes the index numbering the same in both cases?

I've had a look, and I think it would just require a couple of lines of extra code above [Line 109 of _connect/to_pandas.py](https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/uproot/_connect/to_pandas.py#L109), using [pandas.RangeIndex.from_range](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.RangeIndex.from_range.html#pandas.RangeIndex.from_range) along the lines of:
```python
index = pandas.RangeIndex.from_range(range(startentry, stopentry))
```

If you think this would be reasonable to add, I'd be happy to put together a PR along these lines.

title: Best way to produce awkward.Table from tree.arrays
body:
I'm wondering what is the best way to get `tree.arrays` to produce an `awkward.Table`?

The easiest option is to just do:
```python
data = tree.arrays(branches, outputtype=awkward.Table)
```
except that the columns names are `"0"`, `"1"`, etc, rather than the original branch names, which would be nice.

I can also do:
```python
data = tree.arrays(branches, outputtype=tuple)
data = awkward.Table({b: col for b, col in zip(branches, data)})
```
which gives me more meaningful names, but is obviously an extra step with an explicit for-loop.  

Is there an alternative to these that I've missed?

title: Best way to produce an awkward.Table of tree arrays?
body:
I'm wondering what the best way to get a bunch of arrays from a tree and into an awkward.Table is?  

I can do:
```python
data = tree.arrays(branches, outputtype=awkward.Table)
```
but this produces column names of "0", "1", "2", etc, rather than the original branch names.

Alternatively, I can alternatively do:
```python
    data = tree.arrays(branches, outputtype=tuple)                                 
    data = awkward.Table({b: col for b, col in zip(branches, data)})
```
which gives me more meaningful column names, but it's an extra step, and somewhat unsightly.   

Is there any other option that I've missed?

title: JaggedArray method _broadcast has changed to public method tojagged
body:
Hi,

title: Preload chunked data sources
body:
This addresses issue #240, though it only implements step 2 in a generic way that applies to both XRootD and HTTP. It has only been tested on HTTP, and there might be a more specific function to call to do background-loading in XRootD.

The `test_tree.Test.test_hist_in_tree` function was particularly slow using HTTP: 25 seconds. Preloading reduces this time to 5 seconds.

title: Deal with fixed size arrays as part of jagged one
body: This is a proposed fix for reading a branch introduced earlier in the Event.root test

title: Preload data in chunked data sources
body:
1. Chunked sources, when asked for `data` with a given range, should combine tiles into a single request, if possible.
   2. `TBranchMethods.array` should give a complete list of basket byte ranges to the source as a "hint." Only chunked sources use that list: HTTP combines them (does `requests` allow for something like multicurl?) and XRootD uses whatever XRootD's mechanism is to download a batch. If any of these interfaces return an asynchronous future that can be attached to the panel in place of an array, to be handled when we really want the array, so much the better.
   3. `TTreeMethods.iterate` might do something as well, but that would be more complicated.
   4. Lazy arrays (if anybody's using them) would be able to take advantage of this mechanism as well, but in `__getitem__` instead of an `array` method.

title: uproot raises `TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'NoneType' and 'int'` when root file doesn't have TTrees or TBranches
generalize Pandas DataFrame flattening to work with any numeric type, such as Double32
body:
The `tree.pandas.df(flatten=True)` flattening code checks for `asdtype`, but #232 has an `asdouble32` branch. In general, it should check for any `uproot.interp.numerical._asnumeric` (the superclass of numerical interpretations).

So now that's fixed.

title: Add connection period and duration limits to Binder build API curl
body:
The use of `connect-timeout` is to make sure that the curl doesn't try to repeatedly hit the URL if the connection is down or unresponsive for an unreasonably long time. The use of max-time is so that for longer builds the curl doesn't try to follow them for the duration. It just hits the API endpoint and then exits at most 60 seconds later. Additionally the trigger function accepts `--max-time` exit return code, `28`, as valid and then return success.

An [example of this working on a test branch can be found on Travis CI Build #1487](https://travis-ci.org/scikit-hep/uproot/jobs/495674517).

Also [update the launch Binder badge](https://discourse.jupyter.org/t/help-us-choose-an-updated-launch-binder-badge/100).

title: Read Double32_t values with truncated mantissa
body:
This commit implements unpacking of the Double32_t format in which the exponent
and mantissa of the original double value (cast to single precision) are
streamed as 8-bit and 16-bit integers respectively.

Depending on the specification provided by the user the ROOT's Double32_t
values can be packed and streamed to a ROOT file in other two formats. In the
first mode the original double precision values are simply cast to a single
precision and streamed without further manipulation. In the second mode the
double values (again, cast to float and scaled to a given range) are saved as
32-bit integers. These two modes are already taken care of by the
`uproot.interp.auto.interpret()` function and the
`uproot.interp.numerical.asdouble32` interpretation.

For details on Double32_t streaming modes see
https://root.cern/doc/v616/classTBufferFile.html#a44c2adb6fb1194ec999b84aed259e5bc

title: namedecode for elements in branches
body:
Maybe not an issue, but I am still trying to figure out how to fix this.
`namedecode` option correctly decodes branch names but root branches with `std::vector<std::string>` are left as bytes strings.
E.g.

```

rTree = uproot.open(path)[tree]
df = rTree.pandas.df(flatten=False,namedecode='utf-8')
example = df['trigger_triggerName'].iloc[0]
print(example)
print(type(example[0]))

[b'swtrigger_BNB_FEMBeamTriggerAlgo', b'swtrigger_BNB_2017Dec_SWTrigger5PE_FEMBeamTriggerAlgo', b'swtrigger_BNB_HSN_c0_FEMBeamTriggerAlgo']
<class 'bytes'>

```


Should the `namedecode` option apply also to any string in the file?

P.S.: This is fixable in my case, with:
```
df[branchWithListOfStrings] = df[branchWithListOfStrings].apply(lambda strings: [s.decode('utf-8') for s in strings])
```
but I wonder whether it would be desirable to have uproot take care of that.

title: uproot.pandas.df(flatten=True) failing if varying dimensions of branches
body:
I've noticed uproot.pandas.df() smartly giving up on "flatten=True" for root files with branches that have dimensions >1 and use correctly "flatten=True" if dimensions = 0 or 1.

However for root files that have both (many branches with different dimensions), uproot first tried to load everything with flatten=True and then fails. This is easily solvable just forcing "flatten=False", but it might not be immediate for people encountering this problem.

title: "for arrays in uproot.iterate(...)" raises value exception
body:
Hi,

first off, thank you for this great tool.

I'm trying to iterate over multiple root files using this example: https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/README.rst#iterating-over-files-like-tchain, and I'm using this following code snippet for it:

```python
def sortAll():
    targetDir = './numpyPairs/'
    if not os.path.exists(targetDir):
        os.makedirs(targetDir)
    print('using uproot.iterate():')
    try:
        # open the root trees in a TChain-like manner
        for arrays in uproot.iterate('./RootPairs/Lumi_Pairs*.root', 'pndsim', [b'PndLmdHitPair._overlapID', b'PndLmdHitPair._hit1', b'PndLmdHitPair._hit2'], entrysteps=1000000):
            print('processing file...')
            sortPairs(arrays)
    except Exception as e:
        print('error occured:')
        print(e)
    
    print('using naive iteration:')
    # use caveman tactics
    files = [
        './RootPairs/Lumi_Pairs_1000000.root',
        './RootPairs/Lumi_Pairs_0-copy.root'
    ]
    for file in files:
        print('processing file...')
        arrays = uproot.open(file)['pndsim'].arrays([b'PndLmdHitPair._overlapID', b'PndLmdHitPair._hit1', b'PndLmdHitPair._hit2'])
        sortPairs(arrays)
    print('done')
```

I'm using two separate ways to loop over the two root files, because the `uproot.iterate()` function raises a value exception, whereas the naive version works as expected:

```

```

However, from what I can see, the `asjagged(asobj(<uproot_methods.classes.TVector3.Methods>))` objects are identical in both cases, so `tree.py` should not raise this exception. To confirm the problem is not in my data, I symlinked one of the files to the other, so in both cases the content of the root file is identical:


But the problem persists. When I iterate over the files like in the for loop, no error occures.

Best wishes,
Roman Klasen

Edit: I'm using the uproot version from pip3:

```
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

>>> print(uproot.__version__)
```

title: Objects written by uproot and ROOT are read in a different "cycle" order by ROOT
body:
For objects written by uproot, ROOT reads the first object assigned to a TKey.  For objects written by ROOT, ROOT reads the last object assigned to a TKey by default.

I am talking about a situation when the TKey is referred to as key (where key is the name of the TKey) and not key;1 and key;2. 

Objects written by uproot - 

```
>>> import ROOT
>>> import uproot
>>> with uproot.recreate("tmp.root") as f:
...     f["hello"] = "world"
...     f["hello"] = "hi"
... 
>>> f = ROOT.TFile.Open("tmp.root")
>>> str(f.Get("hello"))
'world'
```

I tested and it is the same with histograms. 

Objects written by ROOT - 

```
>>> import ROOT
>>> f = ROOT.TFile("tmp.root", "RECREATE")
>>> h = ROOT.TH1D("another", "", 5, 0, 5)
>>> z = ROOT.TH1D("another", "", 10, -5, 5)
TFile::Append:0: RuntimeWarning: Replacing existing TH1: another (Potential memory leak).
>>> h.Write()
253
>>> z.Write()
258
>>> f.Close()
>>> f = ROOT.TFile.Open("tmp.root")
>>> h = f.Get("another")
>>> h.Draw()
Info in <TCanvas::MakeDefCanvas>:  created default TCanvas with name c1
>>> h = f.Get("another;1")
>>> h.Draw()
Info in <TCanvas::MakeDefCanvas>:  created default TCanvas with name c1
```

Looking at the drawn TCanvas shows that ROOT.TH1D("another", "", 10, -5, 5) is the histogram displayed when executing h = f.Get(another).

title: Speedup TTree.pandas.df(flatten=True) by about factor 8
body:
Hi Jim!

I am working a little bit with the data analysis for the beam tests of the CMS endcap calorimeter upgrade, and we have ROOT files of the following pattern:
* Some branches with basic data types (`int`, `float`)
* Some branches with vectors, all the same length per event

I think the `TTree.pandas.df(flatten=True)` functionality is intended for this use case, but this is about 8 times slower than the equivalent functionality in root_pandas, which everyone therefore wants to use and has to go through the pain of installing ROOT. I realized the bottleneck of uproot is here in the merge:

https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/uproot/_connect/to_pandas.py#L194

Pandas is very slow at merging DataFrames with MultiIndex and the normal Index together, which is happening there: for the basic type branches uproot creates simple DataFrames, for the vector branches DFs with MultiIndices.

It could be significantly sped up by turning the basic type branches into the correct structure by adding them to a JaggedArray of zeros (the broadcasting is just too useful). Additionally, if the broadcasting (or flattening for the awkward arrays) is done in a separate loop over the branches, one can save some code duplication when filling the data frame.

Therefore, this PR should still cover all usecases for `TTree.pandas.df(flatten=True)` but just be much faster. Actually a few ten % faster than root_numpy now. I tested it with an ntuple from the testbeam, with I uploaded here:
https://rembserj.web.cern.ch/rembserj/dumps/ntuple_426.root

What do you think about this? You think it goes in the right direction?

These are the speed benchmarks I did:

```Python
from root_pandas import read_root
import uproot

branches = [u'event', 
       u'rechit_layer','rechit_module', u'rechit_chip', u'rechit_channel', u'rechit_x', u'rechit_y', u'rechit_z',
       u'rechit_energy', u'rechit_amplitudeHigh', u'rechit_amplitudeLow', u'rechit_Tot', 'rechit_toaRise',
       'rechit_TS3High','rechit_TS3Low',  'rechit_TS2High','rechit_TS2Low']

rh_branches = [branch for branch in branches if "rechit" in branch]

%%time
df_root_pandas = read_root("ntuple_426.root",key='rechitntupler/hits',
                           columns=branches, flatten = rh_branches)

%%time
df_uproot = uproot.open("ntuple_426.root")["rechitntupler/hits"].pandas.df(
    branches=branches, flatten=True)
```

Shout-out to @artlbv who originally recognized the slowness and made the comparison with root_pandas!

title: Applied changes in issue #217 of original repository scikit-hep/uproot.
Option in iterate method to access the current file used by uproot.iterate at each step
body:
I open first an issue (actually more of a feature request) instead of directly create a new pull request, so we can discuss first.

I created a virtual environment with _pipenv_ to play a bit with the source code - this is my proposal:

1. make __iterate_ function return by default also the file path from line 162 `for path in paths:`, modifying line 183 as follows,
`yield tree, newbranches, globalentrystart ---> yield tree, newbranches, globalentrystart, path`
2. add a new _reportfile_ argument defaulting to _False_ to the definition of _iterate_,
3. retrieve _path_ from __iterate_, modifying line 125 as follows,
    `for tree, newbranches, globalentrystart in _iterate(.....): ---> for tree, newbranches, globalentrystart, path in _iterate(.....):`
4. add a check to the existing one on `reportentries` in order to take into account all 4 possibilities (both True, only one True and both False), modifying lines from 130 to 133 as follows,
```
    if reportentries:
        yield globalentrystart + start, globalentrystart + stop, arrays
    else:
        yield arrays
```
--->
```
    if reportentries:
        if reportfile:
             yield globalentrystart + start, globalentrystart + stop, arrays, path
        else:
             yield globalentrystart + start, globalentrystart + stop, arrays
    else:
       if reportfile:
             yield arrays, path
       else:
             yield arrays
```
so path will always be the last argument.

I tested such proposed solution successfully on my setup using Python2.


returns

```
{'px1': array([-41.19528764,  35.11804977,  35.11804977, ...,  32.37749196,
        32.37749196,  32.48539387])}
```

so if I do,

```
for arrays in uproot.iterate("Zmumu.root", "events", ["px1"]):

```

I will get the values:

`[-41.19528764  35.11804977  35.11804977 ...  32.37749196  32.37749196, 32.48539387]`

**Python 3.7.0**

```
for arrays in uproot.iterate("Zmumu.root", "events", ["px1"]):
    print(arrays)
```

returns

`{b'px1': array([-41.19528764,  35.11804977,  35.11804977, ...,  32.37749196, 32.37749196,  32.48539387])}`

so the same way to extract the data will fail systematically with a Key error,

title: Problem adding jagged TLorentzVectors
body:
I'm getting an error when trying to add jagged TLorentzVectors. The physics use case is that we need to calculate recoil, which equals met in the signal region and equals met+leading photon pt for a control region. The code snippet below reproduces the error.

Error: `TypeError: (arrays of) TLorentzVector can only be added to/subtracted from other (arrays of) TLorentzVector`

import awkward
import uproot, uproot_methods

offsets=[0,1,3,5]
pts = [50,60,70,80,90,100]
phis = [0.4,0.5,0.6,0.1,0.2,0.3]
etas = [1,2,3,4,5,6]
jagged_pt=awkward.JaggedArray.fromoffsets(offsets,pts)
jagged_phi=awkward.JaggedArray.fromoffsets(offsets,phis)
jagged_eta=awkward.JaggedArray.fromoffsets(offsets,etas)
phos= uproot_methods.TLorentzVectorArray.from_ptetaphi(jagged_pt,jagged_eta,jagged_phi,0)

offsets2=[0,1,2,3]
met_pt = [20,30,40]
met_phi = [0.1,0.2,0.3]
jagged_met_pt = awkward.JaggedArray.fromoffsets(offsets2,met_pt)
jagged_met_phi = awkward.JaggedArray.fromoffsets(offsets2,met_phi)
met = uproot_methods.TLorentzVectorArray.from_ptetaphi(jagged_met_pt,0,jagged_met_phi,0)

highest_pt_pho=phos[phos.pt.argmax()]
recoil = met.zeros_like()
recoil = recoil.cross(highest_pt_pho,nested=True)
recoil = (recoil.i0 + recoil.i1).sum()
recoil += met

title: Http authentication
body:
Resolves #210 

As suggested in #210 I implemented http authentication.
On the way I switched from urllib to [`requests`](http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/).

Now i can do this:
```python
url = "http://data.magic.pic.es/Data/SuperStar/v1/CrabNebula/2014_01_01/20140101_05032025_S_CrabNebula-W0.40+035.root"
file = uproot.open(url, httpsource={"auth": ("username", "password")})
```
raising an `HTTPError` if the authentication is missing or wrong.

Opening non-protected files is the same as before.

The syntax for [authentication](http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/user/authentication/#basic-authentication) is copied from requests.

title: Use Binder build API and use curl to trigger build
body:
As a follow up/fix to PR #202 and a reversion of PR #203 this reapplies the removal of `binder/trigger_binder.py` and its associated selenium and chromium-chromedriver dependencies. It additionally uses `curl` instead of `python -m webbrowser` to ping the Binder build web API to avoid timeout issues and to use the simplest tool possible for a simple job.

```
* Use the Binder build API endpoint with curl to trigger builds
   - https://gitter.im/jupyterhub/binder?at=5c2f87038dafa715c73ff54f
   - https://github.com/jupyterhub/binderhub/blob/9ca8fa68bb8b69c6a2736f2275279583073f314f/examples/binder-api.py#L28
* Remove selenium and chromium-chromedriver dependency installation from Travis CI docs stage
* Remove binder/trigger_binder.py as being able to access the API makes it unnecessary
* Rename stage to binder
```

title: Limit numpy<1.16.0 in PyPy due to Travis CI release lag
body:
In a Travis CI build I was working on for a different upcoming PR I noticed that the [PyPy releases were failing](https://travis-ci.org/scikit-hep/uproot/jobs/479246084). When this bug [was reported to Numpy](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/12654) it was discovered that it seem to be an issue with the versions of PyPy that Travis CI has are old enough to be causing some issues. The [Travis CI response was to use a more recent version of PyPy](https://travis-ci.community/t/issue-travis-ci-fails-for-pypy-code-that-imports-numpy-1-16-0rc1/1680/2) such as `pypy2.7-6.0`.

This PR doesn't do that, but follows the approach that the original Issue reporter [took of limiting the version of NumPy used with the PyPy releases](https://github.com/uqfoundation/mystic/commit/44546990f40464ccbb5a99c00ec722bc6d41b9f7).

If different behavior is desired that can be implemented.

title: Add option in iterate method to jump files which don't have a TTree
body:
Hello!

In ROOT, when issuing a TChain over many files pointing to a particular TTree, it can happen that one or more of such files are missing it (e.g. a malfunctioning subsystem).
In that case, ROOT will just print that it couldn't find the TTree in such files, and it will allow the macro or script to proceed to work on the rest.

I tried to navely use the *iterate* method to reproduce such TChain, but when the method encounters a file which does not have that particular TTree it crashes with a *KeyError*.

There are at least a couple of solutions (not elegant, perhaps):
* import the whole file for each file and then use only that key
* cycle through the files and check if the TTree is there - then concatenate *numpy* arrays (my current workaround)

It would be much more elegant, though, if the iterate method would be patched with an option which jumps over a file which does not have the required TTree (*treepath* in the API documentation).

I apologize if this was somewhat already present and I overlooked it.

In the meanwhile, thank you for your work!
Cheers

title: More histogram intro
body: Minimal extension of the README, which shows how to get the most important data of a histogram. Perhaps some link to uproot-methods should be added as well, to point to further information.

title: TH1D class methods `values`, `allvalues`, `variances`, `allvariances` return lists, not arrays
body: I think they should return numpy arrays instead of lists. numpy is strict dependency for uproot, so it would be ok to return arrays. Returning arrays is more efficient, perhaps they can be views even into the memory of the TH1D object.

title: documentation for histogram unclear
body:
How to use the histogram class in uproot is not clear from the documentation here:
https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot

Could this example please be expanded into one, which shows how to get the basic quantities: the bin edges, the bin values, and the bin variances?

From looking at the methods, it is clear how to get the values (`values` or `allvalues`) and the variances (`variances` or `allvariances`). It is not clear how to get the bin edges in the same way. The method `low` does not return the low edges of all bins, it returns just the lowest edges. Similar for `high`.

I think for consistency, there should be a field which allows to access the bin edges as an array with shape [Nx2], like `[[low_edge0, low_edge1], [low_edge1, low_edge2], ...]`

```
    cache
    const
    interp (package)

    source (package)
    tree
    version
    write (package)

    __version__ = '3.2.14'
    asdebug = asjagged(asdtype('uint8'))

    3.2.14
```

It would be nice if there was some basic overview was displayed instead of the license, similar to what happens when you look at `numpy` in `help()`. I also think that the saying "this code is released under the BSD-3-Clause license" followed by an url to the license text would be better than quoting the license.

I am confused about the DATA field `asdebug`. Shouldn't this be a bool? Is this DATA field really intentionally visible or should it rather be hidden?

title: XRootD-HTTPS support
body:
Hello,

I'm working on some code to read xrootd files via HTTP(s) and have hit an error I don't get. With the following test script

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python

import uproot
f = uproot.open("https://xrootd.accre.vanderbilt.edu:1094/store/data/Run2017E/SingleMuon/NANOAOD/31Mar2018-v1/710000/5400FB33-0A47-E811-AE48-0023AEEEB703.root")
```

with the following patch applied (to relax the SSL settings)
```diff
diff --git a/uproot/source/http.py b/uproot/source/http.py
index 4a1564a..bcc71a1 100644
--- a/uproot/source/http.py
+++ b/uproot/source/http.py
@@ -30,6 +30,7 @@
 
 import os.path
 import re
+import ssl
 try:
     from urllib.request import urlopen, Request
 except ImportError:
@@ -46,6 +47,13 @@ class HTTPSource(uproot.source.chunked.ChunkedSource):
     def __init__(self, path, *args, **kwds):
         super(HTTPSource, self).__init__(path, *args, **kwds)
         self._size = None
+        if path.startswith("http://"):
+            self._sslcontext = None
+        else:
+            # Temporarily disable server cert verfication while I work out how
+            # to always find the grid CA bundle
+            self._sslcontext = ssl.SSLContext(ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23)
+            self._sslcontext.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
 
     defaults = {"chunkbytes": 16*1024, "limitbytes": 16*1024**2}
 
@@ -59,7 +67,7 @@ class HTTPSource(uproot.source.chunked.ChunkedSource):
 
     def _read(self, chunkindex):
         request = Request(self.path, headers={"Range": "bytes={0}-{1}".format(chunkindex * self._chunkbytes, (chun
-        handle = urlopen(request)
+        handle = urlopen(request, context=self._sslcontext)
         data = handle.read()
         if self._size is None:
             m = self._contentrange.match(handle.headers.get("content-range", ""))
```

I get the error
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test.py", line 4, in <module>
    f = uproot.open("https://xrootd.accre.vanderbilt.edu:1094/store/data/Run2017E/SingleMuon/NANOAOD/31Mar2018-v1/710000/5400FB33-0A47-E811-AE48-0023AEEEB703.root")
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/rootio.py", line 80, in open
    return http(path, httpsource)
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/rootio.py", line 101, in http
    return ROOTDirectory.read(openfcn(path), **options)
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/rootio.py", line 164, in read
    streamerkey = TKey.read(source, Cursor(fSeekInfo), streamercontext, None)
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/rootio.py", line 842, in read
    out = cls._readinto(out, source, cursor, context, parent)
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/rootio.py", line 864, in _readinto
    self._fNbytes, self._fVersion, self._fObjlen, self._fDatime, self._fKeylen, self._fCycle, self._fSeekKey, self._fSeekPdir = cursor.fields(source, self._format_small)
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/source/cursor.py", line 70, in fields
    return format.unpack(source.data(start, stop))
  File "/home/meloam/projects/uproot/uproot/source/chunked.py", line 102, in data
    raise IndexError("indexes {0}:{1} are beyond the end of data source {2}".format(gstart + len(chunk), stop, repr(self.path)))
IndexError: indexes 29630001:29630027 are beyond the end of data source 'https://xrootd.accre.vanderbilt.edu:1094/store/data/Run2017E/SingleMuon/NANOAOD/31Mar2018-v1/710000/5400FB33-0A47-E811-AE48-0023AEEEB703.root'
```

Though the file contains `29635611` bytes. I can verify that's what seen by HTTP as well:
```
$ curl -L -k -vvv https://xrootd.accre.vanderbilt.edu:1094/store/data/Run2017E/SingleMuon/NANOAOD/31Mar2018-v1/710000/5400FB33-0A47-E811-AE48-0023AEEEB703.root -o out.txt
$ ls -l out.txt 
-rw-r--r--. 1 meloam cms 29635611 Dec 11 21:08 out.txt
```

I'm not exactly sure of what's going on -- the same file opens fine from the local filesystem -- is it possible there's a silly bug in the chunked source I'm missing? I'm gonna leave this as a placeholder while I try to solve it

title: Fix moved array types.
body:
Hi Jim,

I ran into an error after a fresh install of uproot and awkward from latest pypi versions.
uproot complained about a missing `awkward.util.INDEXTYPE`.

I saw that you moved the types to the base AwkwardArray, and noticed that this change is not yet reflected here in uproot, so I did a quick replacement.

The changes in this PR use `awkward.JaggedArray` where jagged arrays are handled, and `awkward.array.base.AwkwardArray` otherwise.

title: Missing backports.lzma dependency in Python 2.7
body:
Hi Jim,

I just tried to open a ROOT file (CMS nanoAOD) with your latest uproot release from PyPI (3.2.12) in Python 2.7. Apparently, the `backports.lzma` is missing as I see your exception

```
  File ".../lib/python2.7/site-packages/uproot/source/compressed.py", line 90, in decompress
    raise ImportError("\n\nInstall lzma package with:\n\n    pip install backports.lzma --user\nor\n    conda install -c conda-forge backports.lzma\n\n(or just use Python >= 3.3).")
ImportError:

Install lzma package with:

    pip install backports.lzma --user
or
    conda install -c conda-forge backports.lzma

(or just use Python >= 3.3).
```

when simply trying to read a tree via `uproot.open('file.root')["some_key"]`. I saw that it is only required for tests:

https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/f7cc73e34842b731a386ebb8b04d9d4b473c2464/setup.py#L106-L108

Am I doing something wrong, or should `backports.lzma` be moved to `install_requires`?

Thanks!

title: Update ROOT version while writing
body: We should probably merge this in(with the then current version of ROOT), once we have the tests for writing.

title: Add ROOT to Travis CI
body:
Following up on #139.

I've been meaning to create a conda package for ROOT since the [new compilers tools](https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/tasks/build-packages/compiler-tools.html) were added in Anaconda 5. This effort has been waiting on conda-forge  migrating to the new compilers ([current status](https://conda-forge.org/status/)). It has taken a while but is now progressing nicely so I've started building packages on [CERN's GitLab instance](https://gitlab.cern.ch/cburr/root-conda#root-in-conda). I will try to add these these packages to conda-forge once the migration is complete.

This PR adds a new test to the build matrix which uses Python 3.7 to run a small test which is skipped if ROOT is unavailable. I also have packages for Python 2.7 and Python 3.6 so these can be added as well. Alternatively, feel free to close this PR if you'd rather use a different method of getting ROOT into the tests.

title: Implemented std::bitset
body: Strangely, `std::bitset` was simply overlooked in the transition from uproot 2 to 3. The class was sitting there, empty. This PR implements it in the new framework and adds a check for branches inside a TClonesArray, which have a truncated header.

title: Enable compression while writing
body: We set fCompress = 0 while creating a TFile using uproot - This means that the file isn't compressed. We need to add support for writing compressed ROOT files.

title: Duplicate scalar columns (or custom index) in Pandas DF with flatten=True
body: In my case, my tree contains `runNumber` and `eventNumber` columns that I would like to use as an index, but these columns are `NaN` for `subentry != 0`.

title: Can't read custom leaflist struct into Pandas
body:
My tree contains some ordinary branches, and a couple that are structs written with leaflists.

`root_pandas` converts these to separate columns for each leaf, prefixed with the branch name. Uproot generates a single column, with nothing in it.

title: Issue 175
body: Testing issue #175.

title: Type name mismatch for streamer and a corresponding branch for std::pair
body:
There seems to be some inconsistency between the type name know to the streamer on file and the branch type when reading branches automatically created from std::pair members. I am reading a ROOT tree with a simple std::pair<Double_t, Double_t> member split into branches and get the following error:

```
...
File "uproot/uproot/tree.py", line 248, in _attachstreamer
KeyError: b'pair<Double_t,Double_t>'
```
However, a streamer for 'pair<double,double>' does exist and can be used to read the .first and .second subranches. I verified this by simply replacing 'Double_t' with 'double' in `submembers[base]._fTypeName` on line https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/uproot/tree.py#L248 when encounter this branch.

Is this something that can be fixed by mapping ROOT types to their C equivalents? See https://root.cern.ch/doc/master/RtypesCore_8h_source.html#l00031

title: addresses issue #168: provide a way to skip speedbump bytes
body:
because they're sometimes not present.

I couldn't change how these objects are read in general because the speedbump byte is often needed. In this case, it isn't. I can't figure out why, so I've parameterized it.

title: Henryiii filterpandas
body: Continuation of PR #157 with Jim's bug-fixes.

title: "Masks" or "Views" of a tree.
body:
Is there an easy way to "mask" or create a "view" to a TTree read in through uproot?  

Currently in one stage of the processing I'm deciding whether or not events are useful, ie,creating a mask, which is just a numpy array either of bools or a list of indices.  At the moment, if some later part of the code wants to read only "good" events it needs to be given the mask directly, but it would be nice if I could attach this to the tree in some way that I still have all the normal tree methods / interpretations.  I also don't want to pass around large dataframes / structured arrays with the mask already applied since I'm not sure at the point where I make the mask which branches will actually be needed later on.  

My current solution is a wrapper around the tree object itself that applies this mask to the events when any attribute of the tree is accessed which returns events. 

This would offer functionality similar to [TEntryList](https://root.cern.ch/doc/master/classTEntryList.html) I think, though I never really used that very much.

Apologies if this is already solved or has been asked elsewhere, though I checked and couldn't see it mentioned!

title: Migrate from unittest to pytest
body: It's what all the cool kids are using.

title: Adding test and support for None for flatten
body: This addresses #156 , it makes `flatten=None` a possible option when filtering; unlike `False`, this simply removes anything that would need flattening, rather than making them lists. It also adds an *expected failing* test for the current broken `flatten=True` behavior.

title: Filtering pandas df
body:
Currently, there's only one option for reading pandas DataFrames from TTrees that have JaggedArrays: `flatten=True`. However, another use case would be to have a simple way to filter JaggedArrays out.

Currently, this looks like:

```python
good_keys = [key for key in t.keys() if not isinstance(t[key].interpretation, uproot.asjagged)]
t.pandas.df(good_keys, ...)
```

This might be useful in the function call instead. Ideas: `filter=True`, `filter_jagged=True` ,`flatten=None`, `flatten='filter'`, or `jagged='filter'` (`jagged='flatten'` or `multi-index` being another policy) are some ideas.

(This is because I'm dealing with everything-but-the-kitchen-sink NTuples...)

title: Issue148
body:
Adds a `timeout` parameter to XRootDSource, which can be used as following:

```python
import uproot
f = uproot.open("root://wherever//whatever.root", xrootdsource={"timeout": 1})
```

Also in this PR, *Source.defaults have been turned into dicts, rather than functions, and dict-based parameters like `xrootdsource` in the above example override defaults, rather than replacing them completely. That way, you don't need to specify the `chunkbytes` and `limitbytes` if you don't want to.

title: [WIP] Add tests for Jupyter Notebooks
body: Resolves #150

title: Have Selenium properly wait for page load
body: Have Selenium properly wait for the Binder page to load to trigger the Binder build. Just using `time.sleep` is not necessarily sufficient. This is done following the example at [How to get Selenium to wait for page load after a click](http://www.obeythetestinggoat.com/how-to-get-selenium-to-wait-for-page-load-after-a-click.html).

title: Adding support for IPython key completions
body:
Addressing #151 .

Note that completion looks significantly more useful if you press tab before you type a quote - then the key completions are at the top because it sorts the completions, and the quote `'` causes the key completions to be at the top. Not sure why Jupyter assumes any other sort of completion inside a string for a key...

Only tested locally on Python 3, will use CI to test Python 2.

title: Support IPython completion
body:
IPython supports key completion in dictionary like objects. In order to support it, a list of possible key completions should be returned from `_ipython_key_completions_()`. If you manually hack this in a notebook:

```python
d.__class__._ipython_key_completions_ = lambda x: [x.decode() for x in x.keys()]
```

Then type:

```python
d[
```

Then press tab, you'll get `'HitStrips;1'` as a possible completion (in my case, `d` is a `TDirectory`). The ";1" could also be stripped on directories, as it's not needed as a key.

It would be nice if all dictionary-like classes supported this method in uproot.

Edit: My usage of decode in the hack is Python 3.

title: Test Jupyter Notebooks in papermill
body:
The Jupyter notebooks should all be run in the CI with papermill to make sure that active development doesn't break documentation.

`pyhf` does this, so for reference see the [notebook tests that we have for `pyhf`](https://github.com/diana-hep/pyhf/blob/master/tests/test_notebooks.py).

title: Trigger Binder to build image on pushes to master
body: Use selenium to trigger Binder to have repo2docker start the build of the image anytime a new push to master occurs. This ensures that there will always be a recently built Binder example so that if someone clicks on the launch Binder badge they don't have to wait for it to build. selenium is used instead of just `python -m webbrowser` as the browser needs to be open on the URL long enough for Binder to trigger.

title: Issue133
body: Fixes #133

title: Move conversion code to methods
body:
uproot-methods 0.2.0 takes over the responsibility of recognizing data (e.g. histograms) from other packages. uproot will now depend on `uproot-methods>=0.2.0`.

Implemented Numpy and physt in both directions (reading and writing).

title: Issue136
body: Fixes #136 and #134.

title: Unit tests for writing!
body: The writing feature doesn't "fully" exist until there are unit tests. There's a stub for adding unit tests, such as the ones we've been running interactively. I'll add some, you add some, and I'll find a way to put PyROOT in the Travis tests for automatically verifying that ROOT can read what we write.

title: Nested TDirectories
body:
The `TDirectory` code is very likely naive hard-coding assumptions that only hold true for the root directory. It should be possible to generalize this and therefore add nested directories.

This is probably related to question #128, in which @sbinet created such a file in Go-HEP, but had trouble reading it in ROOT. There seems to be something subtle about `TDirectories`.

The Python interface should still be through `__setitem__`. In this case, a name with slashes (`/`) should be used to navigate through nested directories, just as it is for reading data. (This is why there's a stub of "if `/`, raise NotImplementedError.") Don't create subdirectory objects (as is possible in the reading code) because the distributed mutability would be a nightmare.

title: More histogram, profile, and graph types
body:
It should be easy to expand the 1-d histogram implementation to all classes that inherit from `TH1` in ROOT (1, 2, and 3-d histograms and profile plots). `TGraph` and `TMultiGraph` are a separate problem not only do they need streamers (see #131), but they don't inherit from `TH1` and adding them would be a similar process to adding `TH1`.

Go-HEP has `TGraphs` and would be a good guide.  :)

title: Make uproot-written files appendable in ROOT
body: Files written in uproot can be read in ROOT, but so far they can't be added to in ROOT (i.e. opening the file as a `"UPDATE"` TFile and putting new objects in it). The solution could be as simple as setting `nfree` to 1, rather than 0; we simply haven't investigated it, but it's an important feature to have.

title: Block management
body:
Currently, reusing a key name or deleting a key reuses the space used by the key but not the value. The behavior is formally correct, but it is inefficient: assigning new histograms to the same name will make the output file length grow indefinitely. To handle this properly, we need to view the linear sequence of bytes in a file as reusable blocks, rather than a stream.

There are many algorithms that do this. ROOT must have one, for instance, and this is essentially what `malloc` does with RAM memory. This is an open-ended project involving some thinking about design. These systems are prone to fragmentation; perhaps introducing a (not too small, not too large) granular unit of allocation helps. Perhaps that unit can be 4K to match most filesystems, which read in 4K blocks.

Designs should probably be tested outside of the uproot codebase and only integrated when a good solution is found. Maybe there's a library that does it, though I doubt that. (I'd even have a hard time looking for a search term: by what name do computer scientists refer to this problem?) Once you have a good solution, it should be integrated into `TFile._expandfile` so that both new values and new keys can take advantage of it.

title: UUID must be properly set
body: ROOT's TFile UUID [is defined here](https://root.cern.ch/doc/v612/classTUUID.html) and follows the [RFC 4122 standard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#Format). This is a 16-byte standard; I'm not sure what the other two bytes are (it's 18-bytes in the TFile header), but you can probably find that. [Python's uuid library](https://docs.python.org/3/library/uuid.html) provides UUIDs in this format.

title: Datime timestamps need to be properly formatted
body: Right now, they're constants. Write an algorithm that converts time from Python's `time` or `datetime` library into this format and properly fill them in everywhere they appear (`TDirectory` and `TKey`; search for "FIXME").

title: Write custom fLabels
body:
Each axis has a `fLabels` member for labeling the axis with strings, rather than numbers. Physicists do use this regularly. Currently, `fLabels` is in the short block that we "punted" on, raising a `NotImplementedError` if `fLabels` is not empty.

File `tests/samples/issue33.root` has an example of a histogram with labels. Use this as an example to handle `fLabels` properly.

title: Script to make streamers
body:
Streamers are hard-coded in uproot, covering a superset of the types of objects we can write. (We'll never write types from Python that aren't known in C++. That wouldn't be fair: there would be no C++ classes to fill, so they'd be unusable in C++. The point of writing from uproot is to subsequently use the data in C++.)

I needs to be possible to generate this hard-coded streamer list from a script. That script would only ever be used by developers.

The script should also have a way of checking streamer version numbers because we need to generate objects according to the same streamer definitions that we put into the file. This can be manual or automatic, but the more automated, the better. It only needs to be a one-time check between the code and the generated streamers, though: no need to check anything at runtime.

title: Maximum recursion depth exceeded for caches
body:
Caches end up in an infinite loop if the user adds the memory cache as an item to itself. I realise this shouldn't be done but there's nothing stopping the user from doing this or even adding a `dict` or nested `dict` which contains the memory cache and so might not be easy to spot.

The [`sizeof`](https://github.com/scikit-hep/uproot/blob/master/uproot/cache/memorycache.py#L86) is where the the infinite recursion starts. This function can recurse over certain objects and if this object is the cache itself then it will get stuck in a loop.

My suggestion is to check that the user doesn't add an item to the cache which is the cache itself at some point or skip `sizeof` acting on the cache itself (but you might not want a nested cache anyway). This will prevent them getting the infinite recursion which spits out the error below at somepoint:

```
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 88, in <genexpr>
    return sys.getsizeof(obj) + sum(MemoryCache.sizeof(k) + MemoryCache.sizeof(v) for k, v in obj.items())
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 98, in sizeof
    out += MemoryCache.sizeof(x)
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 88, in sizeof
    return sys.getsizeof(obj) + sum(MemoryCache.sizeof(k) + MemoryCache.sizeof(v) for k, v in obj.items())
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 88, in <genexpr>
    return sys.getsizeof(obj) + sum(MemoryCache.sizeof(k) + MemoryCache.sizeof(v) for k, v in obj.items())
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 98, in sizeof
    out += MemoryCache.sizeof(x)
  File "uproot/cache/memorycache.py", line 91, in sizeof
    elif isinstance(obj, (unicode, str)):
RuntimeError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
```

title: Conditional Importing of Entries
body:
Hello!  I'd just like to say that `uproot` looks like really exciting software.  I'd like to move my own tracking software for the COMET experiment from `root_numpy` to `uproot`.

One feature I appreciate in `root_numpy` is the `selection` parameter.  
```
selection : str, optional (default=None)

    Only include entries fulfilling this condition. If the condition evaluates to multiple values per tree entry (e.g. conditions on array branches) then an entry will be included if the condition evaluates to true for at least one array element.
```

I was wondering if any idioms exist for similar behavior in `uproot`.  That is to say, for a tree with branches ['a', 'b', 'c'] that are all fundamental dtypes (and not vectors),  is it possible to only import entries into a numpy array where (a < 5) and (c > 3)?

I feel like this is probably already possible using the existing code, given the extensive breadth of memory-management and iteration-through-a-tree available in `uproot`. Perhaps you already know of an idiom that can iterate through the data, only storing entries that satisfies some requirement on the components of the entry?  Maybe something like, read in block of data, check data, store good data, continue. 

If nothing comes to mind immediately, I'll look into it when I make the switch in a month or so.  Thanks for all your hard work!

title: ROOT file format per uproot
body:
I have a couple use-cases that would benefit from a ROOT-less C++ or Java interface to ROOT files, and I'm wondering if it might be possible to describe the ROOT file structure with e.g. Kaitai Struct (http://kaitai.io/) or a DFDL schema (https://daffodil.apache.org/).

It seems like this is at least close to what the uproot parser currently does; does anyone know of any documentation on the ROOT format I might refer to?

Apologies if the appropriate thing to do is buckle down and work through the uproot code!  I thought I'd ask just in case there's a great resource I just haven't been able to find.

title: Add parameter `namedecode` to give users names as `str`, not `bytes`.
Strings encoded as bytes
body:
Hi Jim,
Reminder issue from our quick chat at QCHS, as requested.

Uproot encodes strings as bytes, and would be nice if there were the option to decode into UTF-8 when calling functions.
My particular issue is with the column names when exporting to a Padas dataframe, e.g.:
```
rootData = uproot.open(splitDir + "125.root")['mu_tau'].pandas.df()
rootData.head()
```
Produces a dataframe with columns names:

`b't_0_pT'  b't_0_eta'  b't_0_phi'  b't_0_mass' b't_0_mT' b't_1_pT'`

Currently my work around is to run:
`rootData.columns = [x.decode("utf-8") for x in rootData.columns]`

But it would be more convenient to be able to request UTF-8 when exporting the dataframe, and with similar functions, too.

Thanks,
Giles.

title: PEP 519: Path protocol support
body:
Uproot currently does not support pathlib, so something like this will fail:

```python
from pathlib import Path
import uproot
p = Path('/data/file.root')
f = uproot.open(p) # Error
```

The path and similar functions should use `name = os.fspath(name)` if `os` has `fspath` (depends slightly on what sort of objects uproot accepts here). (This is the correct solution for Python 3.6+, and will also support other path objects in libraries like Plumbum; anything that provides a `__fspath__()` method. It won't fix the pathlib backport on Py2, or Python < 3.6.)

See https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0519 .

title: Better support for zero-entry trees
body:
Hi,

I am enjoying trying out uproot.  In trying to look at the dask support, I ran into the following when trying to read a file with an empty tree (one can of course get these occasionally when running on the output of skim jobs):

```
>>> t.numentries
0
>>> t.lazyarrays(branches=['RunNumber', 'EventNumber'])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/eos/user/p/ponyisi/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py", line 514, in lazyarrays
    lazyarrays = [(branch.name, branch.lazyarray(interpretation=interpretation, limitbytes=limitbytes, cache=cache, basketcache=basketcache, keycache=keycache, executor=executor)) for branch, interpretation in branches]
  File "/eos/user/p/ponyisi/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py", line 1427, in lazyarray
    return LazyArray._frombranch(self, interpretation, cache, basketcache, keycache, executor)
  File "/eos/user/p/ponyisi/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/uproot/tree.py", line 1742, in _frombranch
    self._chunksize = max(onlybranch.basket_numentries(i) for i in range(onlybranch.numbaskets))
ValueError: max() arg is an empty sequence
>>>
```
As far as I can tell, replacing the expression by "max() if onlybranch.numbaskets > 0 else 1" makes things work.

ETA: it seems for uproot.daskframe() to work, the chunksize() function in lazyarrays() needs to be fixed too.

Best,
Peter

body:
When attempting to access a THnSparseF via uproot, the output of `repr()` and `dir()` on the object is:

```
THnSparse: <Undefined (no class named 'THnSparseT<TArrayF>', version 1) at 0x000111a3c668>
Available attributes: ['__class__', '__delattr__', '__dict__', '__dir__', '__doc__', '__eq__', '__format__', '__ge__', '__getattribute__', '__gt__', '__hash__', '__init__', '__init_subclass__', '__le__', '__lt__', '__metaclass__', '__module__', '__ne__', '__new__', '__reduce__', '__reduce_ex__', '__repr__', '__setattr__', '__sizeof__', '__str__', '__subclasshook__', '__weakref__', '_classname', '_classversion', '_copycontext', '_cursor', '_postprocess', '_readinto', 'read']
```

From exchanging a few emails with Jim, I understand that this indicates that the streamer is not yet implemented - this issue is intended to get this discussion going.

To aid in testing, a root file containing the example THnSparseF (named "testSparse") is available [here](https://github.com/ALICEYale/alice-yale-dev/raw/master/analyses/uproot/testSparse.root). It is quite trivial - it contains a number of axes and has been filled with a few entries. It can be recreated using the code [here](https://github.com/ALICEYale/alice-yale-dev/blob/master/analyses/uproot/uprootSparse.py) (note that it will fail on an assertion because it attempts to access a member which is not available yet, but the test file will be created anyway).

title: Jagged indexing
body:
Dear authors,

I am storing the number of few active pixels in a jet image as array and I am reading them out as a jaggedArray. I would like then to re-build the jet as an image on the fly. I tried:

```python
imgs = np.zeros((4,3,3))
imgs[:, sample['ix'], sample['iy']] = sample['iv']
```

but of course it does not work. Here ix, iy, and iv are the x index, y index, and value of each active cell, respectively.
For this to work think I would need a simple feature addition that returns the x index for each element. Would it make sense to you to implement it? Any suggestion for a quick and elegant hack to work in the meantime? 

Thanks
